Discussion of several books pertaining to Alexander family history and genealogy, with the prices and instructions for ordering them. Offers to send copies of letters concerning their Alexander ancestors.

div.p: Mrs. E.A.R. Breck
Cor. Main & Cumberland Sts.
Knoxville
Tenn
Franklin, Tenn.
My dear friend & relative:-

I was so much pleased to receive your Christmas card, & that you gave me a thought during the Christmas festivities. Since I last wrote to you, have learned a great deal about our ancestors. It seems that our great-great-grandfather, James Alexander, lived in Cecil Co, Md. & I dont think even went to N.C. His sins John McKnitt, & Hezekiah, & daughter Jemima Sharp were all born in Md. or Penn. & they emigrated to N.C.

James Alexander was twice married, his first-wife was Margaret McKnitt, a daughter of John McKnitt an attorney in Md. His second wife I think was named Abigail. By his first-wife he had Theophilus, Jemima, Edith, Kiziah, Ezekiel, Hezekiah, Amos, John McKnitt & Margaret. It seems that James Alexander's people settled first in Del - then went to Md. & Penn. James Alexanders will is recorded at the Court House, in Elkton, Cecil Co. Md. A Mrs. Francis Alexander Butterworth of Chicago, has gotten out

a book called "A family of the House of Alexander". In the preparation of this book she visited Md. Va., Penn. N.C. & other places - looked up all the old court records & c. Gen. Alexander Evans of Baltimore, retired army officer, lately deceased, & a decendant of A,os Alexander, gave her the clues to work upon. She says the similarity of names running all through the Alexander family could not be accidental. Her great uncle was James Alexander, & his brothers Amos, Hezekiah & c. Man our James Alexander must have
been her great uncle, for he had sons named Amos, & Hezekiah. In the back of her book she has James Alexanders will.

A large colony of Alexanders settled in Md. Penn. & Va - In Md. they owned vast estates. She says we are descendants of the Earls of Stirling, so that must account for the crowns upon my tree. A Mrs. Thomas Polk of Jackson a descendant of Jemima Alexander Sharp - sent me a number of letters she had rec'd from Mrs. Butterworth, which I copied, & will send to you for perusal, as soon as they are

returned to me. Mr. Sharp of Nashville has them now. The finest genealogical library in this country is in Chicago, & one of the letters of Mrs. Butterworth contains data copied from this library about James Alexander our ancestor. I have just purchased one of Mrs. Butterworths books. It contains the Alexander Coat of Arms, pictures of some of the manor houses in Md. old wills & c. I paid $2.00 for it. I have also gotten the History of
Mecklenburg Co. N.C. & "Biographical Sketches of the Hopewell Section" written by Dr. John Brenard Alexander. You should have these, for there is so much in them about John McKnitt Alexander.

This John Brenard Alexander's mother was Abbie Caldwell, & his fathers a grandson of John McKnitt Alexander. He is very feeble & blind. His daughter Annie LourieAlexander is an M.D. Should you wish these books, write to Dr. J.B. Alexander Charlotte N.C. The History of
Mecklenburg Co., is $2.25, & the Biographical Sketches of the Hopewell Section is 50 cents. this includes postage on the books.
The House of Alexander is 2.00 & is obtained from Mrs. Frances Butterworth 5517 Cornell Avenue, Chicago, Ills.

Mrs. Hester Darsey Richardson is getting out some books entitled "Americans of Aristocratic Birth" & is anxious to include the Alexanders if the heirs are sufficiently interested to pay for it. Says she has the
data of the family back in Scotland & Ireland.
Mrs. Butterworths uncle was named Adam Rankin Alexander, & Judge Alexander's father was also named Adam Rankin Alexander. Isnt it singular how similar the names are.

I sent one of Mrs. Butterworths letters to Mr. McClung, last week, & told him to show it to you. I doubt if either of you can read it. Her penmanship is horrible. After many efforts I have at last been able to decipher her writing. If you can not read it, I will copy it for you. Just as soon as Mr. Sharp returns my
letters will send them to you - for I know they will interest you.
Wishing you much happiness, & prosperity for the year 1911.
I am
Sincerely
Nellie Alexander Gordon.
